Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2008 08:47AM morning wrote: Oh, Keryl, That PET scan gave some hard news. I'm sorry your fear factor has been extended. As to the sentinel node pain, what happened with me is that the dye didn't go into the sentinel node. It never showed up after the radioactive injection, so My BS just grabbed a gob of stuff out of my armpit and had it biopsied. Of course, there were several nodes in it. They were clean. But I have the pain you described only it's down the back of my arm. And honestly, now at six months it is much less sharp and happens less often. Please let us know how you fare with this new development pain-wise and recovery-wise, and especially malignancy-wise.
Posts.Title: Anyone with severe SNB Pain? Knives in armpit! Keryl morning

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2008 10:43AM morning wrote: Beautiful metaphor, Swimangel. God knows you've been through a river of fire. I so relate to this depression thing. I have embarrassed myself by crying miserably in front of the very people who were my staunch support system. One day I cried until my sinuses were just screaming. My mother, my kids, and my friends sat by feeling helpless. I wish I hadn't done that. But, it is what I felt. I guess it was partly post-surgical and mostly the awful dawning fact that I really did have cancer. Also, there are the sleep problems that go with a mastectomy. The sleeping on my back is like an unnatural act. I went on anti-depressants, but still I get what I call "breakthrough weeping." I've seldom been depressed in my life, and I have to say, I''m impressed. It's a terrible, and kind of dangerous thing to be. Next time somebody in my world is depressed, believe me, I'm going to take it seriously.
Posts.Title: Identity and late-night tears LorenaB cp418

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2008 10:51AM morning wrote: I was so scared. I used the lidocaine, but didn't have much faith in it. My sister held my hand, and it was over soon enough. If you think about it, it really is ingenious. To shoot the dye in and have it go to the first node. Some of the things the doctors have done through all this, are downright brilliant.

Waiting for tests again! morning Dukemom2

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2008 05:15PM morning wrote: Waiting's over and the news is good. My ovaries were normal and my chest xray clear. The radiologist even checked out the part of my spinal column that could be seen in the chest xray. I think I'm beginning to trust my body again. For awhile there, I thought it had turned on me. Wishiwere, Have you gotten your test results back?
Posts.Title: Waiting for tests again! morning Dukemom2

Posts.Content: morning wrote: I just got back from having an ultrasound of my ovaries and a chest xray. I was worried about the chest thing because I cough a lot and because stairs bother me. But the ovary thing wasn't worrying me much. However, the technician concentrated so hard on the right ovary and took so many pictures, that I began to tremble with fear. I won't know 'til Wednesday, and that's if my harried pcp gets around to calling. This is the summer of waiting and fear. So much fear. What will you do with your one wild and precious life? Posts.Title: Waiting for tests again! morning Dukemom2

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2008 04:54PM morning wrote: Oh, Gosh, thanks for answering so quick. I just had a bilateral mastectomy, and the pelvic scan was ordered because I have a family history of ov cancer. Not Breast. Which I got. I just can't help remembering that terrible night when my pcp called me and said the biopsy showed that I had cancer in my breast. Oh, Jeeez. That couldn't happen to a person twice in a  year. Oh, yeah, it could. We wait together. I thank  you for being there. There sure is a lot of waiting when you get enmeshed in the medical system.
Posts.Title: Waiting for tests again! morning Dukemom2

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2008 09:38PM morning wrote: Well, I know that once you've committed yourself to the medical model,  you call  your doctor a lot, but i find that we' re in the Hallowed halls of Specialty. Breast surgeons, plastic surgeons and radiologists and oncologists do not remember the simple things we learned as mothers and wise women. Try some benadryl..not topical. Oral. check on medline first to see if it is contraindicated or problematic with anything you're already taking. Then take some and go to bed. Because it will give you a good night's sleep too. It's an Over the counter drug. Shouldn't be too toxic.
Posts.Title: SNB incision itches! bettelou68 morning

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2008 02:28AM morning wrote: longhorn, Your situation is truly scary. In my own small way, I feel your fear. The fact that you're applying for an adoption tells me you are young. This is a terrific challenge. please stay with us and let us walk with you through this valley of courage. Prayers, blessings and constant outreach come from us on this board. Keep us up on your path reports.
Posts.Title: Ready To Hear PET results LongHornSurvivor crazydaisy

Posts.Content: morning wrote: Sometimes, now, when I'm with my friends, I do this silly thing. I count off one to seven. And I worry. I think that the hardest thing I could ever hear, since the night my doctor called and told me I had breast cancer, would be to hear that one of my friends or my sisters, or godforbid, my daughters had it.   Of course, to be in a room and count off sevens is a naive way to look at statistics because, of course, it's much more random than that. But still, the thought that this could happen to someone I love makes me want to cry. Then, I realize how really awful this has been. You can put on your brave face so well, that you start to believe that it wasn't so bad. But then you think of it happening to someone else,  it comes right up in your face. This has been the scariest, loneliest, most painful time in my life. Maybe I shouldn't post this because I'm not expressing myself very well, but I will post it anyway, in case one of you read it and can relate to it and put it in better words. What will you do with your one wild and precious life? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: One in Seven! morning rrs

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2008 02:37PM morning wrote: I had my n/c biopsy done sitting up, although I had thought it would be on a table.It was moderately uncomfortable, but I think, deep down, I knew that if I'd gotten to this step in the diagnostic process, I was probably screwed. I was right. So, I passed out cold, pulling my breast out of the press. I laugh now when I think of the first thing I heard when I came to. The lab assistant was saying to the doctor, " I hate it when their eyes roll back in their head."
Posts.Title: Core Biopsy Pain Estepp suems

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2008 11:17AM morning wrote: emath, The waiting is so hard. If you can't get a good plan in place soon, you might consider finding a Breast Center in some major hospital, seeing the team and getting a treatment plan. The posts above are right. A few months won't change things much. Not with the cancer. But you can only take so much stress. For your peace of mind, sooner is really better. Meanwhile, one of the mantras that I used to get through the waiting was, " My cancer is on me- not in me."
Posts.Title: Ok, so I have cancer emath jdg1

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2008 04:27AM morning wrote: Oh, Girl, I so get your disappointment. and sorrow. I had the same thing happen and on my right side as well. I felt like the dickens and he didn't decide to take it out until I couldn't stop crying. What was left was this funny drain that looked like half a rubber tube rolled into a hole in my ex-breast. It drained for a few weeks into gauze pads that I changed often. Towards the end, it sucked air and sounded funny. Anyway, I went home with one side flat and one side expanding. I was depressed and embarrassed . I thought I looked like a freak. At first I wore bras with whatever stuck in them. Then I discovered that, frankly, nobody looks at you. I began to wear these cute little smock tops and didin't bother with stuffing the flat side.Then after a while, I was actually proud of it.  I've been through a lot, folks, and don't you forget it. But here's what I learned.. I Do want reconstruction. Given one side all puckered and sad, and the other side, expanding, square, uncomfortable, but hopeful... I'll take my chances with more reconstruction. Three months after the staph debacle, on July 23, I went back and got an expander put back in the right side. The surgery should have taken 2 hours, but it took 4 and a half because the "minimal staph contamination (docs words) had decimated my pectoralis major and he had to patch and repair with alloderm. Also, it had tunneled between my breast site and my underarm, so he had to fix that too. It is a month since that surgery...my third counting the blm, and I am tired, I take too many pills many of which are psychotropic...xanax, amytriptaline. And one big one for my blood pressure which may be closely associated to my psychological condition. I do relaxation exercises when I take my mandatory nap. I read Thich Nhat Han. Try to live in the moment. What do I have now. One great squarish expander, and one new miniature one that actually has a certain breast-like roundness to it. That is the new right one.Still wearing my little Target smock shirts. I have to drive to Denver from the Western Slope of Colorado for fills. (Cancelled next week's due to the democratic convention.) And, given that all things go well, I have one more surgery. That will make four surgeries. Two of them so far have exceeded all my notions of how long it is good to be artificially anesthetized. Oh, yes, my dear, this is a big setback. You can do it. And the more you look at your flat side and eventually palpate that concavity that is left after your breast is gone, the more determined you are to make it work. Somebody told me that I had to expect to give this cancer experience a year of my life. I thought because I was fit and strong and psychologically solid, that maybe I could beat that. But the truth is, that including the reconstruction, I'll be lucky if a year covers it. Either way. I'm alive and it's a beautiful day! Good luck to you, girl. My heart is so with you.
Posts.Title: Removal of Tissue Expander due to Infection csifinski Kinclan

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2008 10:25PM morning wrote: If I've learned anything from BC, it's that a feeling is just a feeling. When I looked, I was alarmed, even full of shame, but, those are just feelings and they passed. I spent the next few months with one side expanded...badly, and the other side all crumpled, waiting for the infection to pass.At first I avoided the mirror most of the time, But then I just got used to it.It's a tribute to the design of the human spirit, that we can get used to almost anything. I have talked to people who know they're dying and, at first they go into total freak-out mode, but then with time, they settle down and do what needs to be done, and even regain their sense of humor. I guess one of the wisest people in the twentieth century was Elizabeth Kubler Ross, who gave us the stages of grief. They apply to everything from a stained carpet, to amputation, and even to death. Smart Lady. Anyway, Route, I love that you come to our group. Tell your darling lady that she needs to be careful. We'll all be falling in love with you.
Posts.Title: Getting your first peek after Skin Sparing Mastectomy Route53 Route53

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2008 02:15PM morning wrote: Courage, dear. Did you ever notice how, when you happily anticipate something, before you know it, it's over?  And you can't believe that it's already past? Well, your surgery and healing will be the same. You'll be in pre-op and saying to yourself, "Well, it's finally happening." Then before  you know it, it'll be over. You can do this, because you must. Good luck, Quick healing, and be glad for all the good things your doctors have learned about how to treat you.

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2008 05:51PM morning wrote: This happened to me with my expander and I ended up having it taken out. I am now waiting for the re-installation in July. The Keflex and cipro are so hard on the stomach. My oncologist suggested a fitness bar found in the health food store. It is in the refrigerator section and is called Attune. It's full of probiotics.
Posts.Title: Right Foob is red MsSherry MsSherry

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2008 10:42PM morning wrote: Gawd, I'm getting tired of hearing these surgeons who won't do a BLM when the patient requests it.Of course, they will be long gone by the time  you need the second mastectomy, after years of worry and fear. They treat the "healthy" breast as if it were the virtuous child, the holy grail of pulchritude. I swear, I think they have a fixation. Didn't their mothers nurse them long enough? Viktoria, I have to tell you that my first meltdown came when I realized I had to go back home with "one shoe on and one shoe off." Mine wasn't because of a nutcase surgeon, because I had a bilateral. But I was going home with only one expander and the other a little ruined pucker of ugly flesh. I cried and cried. They called the social worker, and I told her I was afraid people would look at me.She was about 10 years old and wrote down everything I said, and used her best Rogerian technique. I went home, bought about seven smocked tops from Target... they're quite the style right now. I got a padded bra and put whatever I could find in the flat side. Those round nursing pads gave it a little bit of lift. I tried a sock...mmm socks are for feets not fronts. I even filled a toe of a little footlet sock with millet and tied if off in a  knot that was supposed to simulate a nipple. ( Got  that off the internet.)Not a great solution either. Got the giggles when I realized that the darned stuff could germinate in there and I could have sprouts for dinner. Finally, I realized that NOBODY'S LOOKING AT MY BREASTS! Now that's the common ordinary truth. We are all little floating islands, barely noticing each other. This one is worried about her hair. That one is thinking about his stomach. Another is thinking about her protuding teeth, but nobody gives a sh..t about our breasts. After awhile, I wore the different size breasts with pride. I've been through a lot. And if anyone notices, good for them, maybe they've stepped outside the vortex of their own narcissism. Give them gratitude and move on. I hate to think how afraid I was to be seen all lopsided. It was a fear with absolutely no ground. Anybody need a bag of millet?
Posts.Title: lop sided for 6-8 weeks - help Viktoria vhqh
